title: How to Make Healthy Marshmallow Sweet Potatoes

steps.headline: Peel sweet potatoes, for instance with a potato peeler or knife.
steps.description: A small sharp non-serrated knife, preferably without a pointy point (to protect the user), is a good option. The skin is thin and the potatoes are hard, so take a narrow strip at a time to avoid jamming the knife and also to avoid wasting potato. Sweet potatoes are not very easy to peel safely so generally don't let a child do this.

steps.headline: Chop the sweet potatoes into disks about an inch thick.
steps.description: Set them on the baking dish. Ideally they will form a single layer, closely packed, an inch thick side by side. Overlap them if you have to.

steps.headline: Put a cup of water in the baking dish, cover it with an oven-proof mostly-tight cover such as aluminium foil, and bake for 30 minutes or so, at 350 degrees or so.
steps.description: The temperature doesn't really mater so long as it is well above 212 degrees, the boiling point of water--whatever temperature you're baking something else at should be fine.

steps.headline: Take out the baking dish, confirm that the potatoes have softened with a fork, and tilt the dish to drain off most of the water.

Sprinkle the sugar (1/4 cup or so for a bread pan, 1/2 cup or so for a square pan, and 3/4 to 1 cup for a big rectangular pan), spices (a dusting, perhaps 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon for a bread pan, 1 teaspoon for a square pan, and 2 teaspoons for a rectangular pan; a little less of something else mild like nutmeg, and much less of something strong like cloves.)
steps.description: Re-cover and bake for 30 minutes or so more.

steps.headline: You could add a layer of marshmallows (one continuous layer of mini-marshmallows or one somewhat spaced layer of large ones) when adding the spices.
steps.description: The problem is that marshmallows are just fluffed sugar and corn syrup, which tend to de-foam like soap bubbles and turn into still-tasty but not-so-interesting syrup when heated through.

steps.headline: For better appearance, uncover the spiced and sugared sweet potatoes after they've cooked a half-hour or so, cover them with marshmallows, check that nothing else is in the oven, and broil them for a minute or so to lightly brown the surface without the heat penetrating much through the airy marshmallows.
steps.description: The hot sweet potatoes will soften them sufficiently from underneath to give them a somewhat soft appealing texture.

steps.headline: Allow to cool to being merely warm (check the sweet potatoes or the bottom of the pan, not the marshmallow topping, which due to being insulated will be cool on the outside when the inside is still hot) and serve.
The result should be a browned thin marshmallow topping with soft but not mushy sweet potato chunks underneath, each in a sweet, aromatic, dark-speckled syrupy coating.

text: Peel sweet potatoes, for instance with a potato peeler or knife. A small sharp non-serrated knife, preferably without a pointy point (to protect the user), is a good option. The skin is thin and the potatoes are hard, so take a narrow strip at a time to avoid jamming the knife and also to avoid wasting potato. Sweet potatoes are not very easy to peel safely so generally don't let a child do this. Chop the sweet potatoes into disks about an inch thick. Set them on the baking dish. Ideally they will form a single layer, closely packed, an inch thick side by side. Overlap them if you have to. Put a cup of water in the baking dish, cover it with an oven-proof mostly-tight cover such as aluminium foil, and bake for 30 minutes or so, at 350 degrees or so. The temperature doesn't really mater so long as it is well above 212 degrees, the boiling point of water--whatever temperature you're baking something else at should be fine. Take out the baking dish, confirm that the potatoes have softened with a fork, and tilt the dish to drain off most of the water.  Sprinkle the sugar (1/4 cup or so for a bread pan, 1/2 cup or so for a square pan, and 3/4 to 1 cup for a big rectangular pan), spices (a dusting, perhaps 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon for a bread pan, 1 teaspoon for a square pan, and 2 teaspoons for a rectangular pan; a little less of something else mild like nutmeg, and much less of something strong like cloves.) Re-cover and bake for 30 minutes or so more. You could add a layer of marshmallows (one continuous layer of mini-marshmallows or one somewhat spaced layer of large ones) when adding the spices. The problem is that marshmallows are just fluffed sugar and corn syrup, which tend to de-foam like soap bubbles and turn into still-tasty but not-so-interesting syrup when heated through. For better appearance, uncover the spiced and sugared sweet potatoes after they've cooked a half-hour or so, cover them with marshmallows, check that nothing else is in the oven, and broil them for a minute or so to lightly brown the surface without the heat penetrating much through the airy marshmallows. The hot sweet potatoes will soften them sufficiently from underneath to give them a somewhat soft appealing texture. Allow to cool to being merely warm (check the sweet potatoes or the bottom of the pan, not the marshmallow topping, which due to being insulated will be cool on the outside when the inside is still hot) and serve.  The result should be a browned thin marshmallow topping with soft but not mushy sweet potato chunks underneath, each in a sweet, aromatic, dark-speckled syrupy coating.
